column1: Noginsk (Russian: Ноги́нск) is a city and the administrative center of Noginsky District in Moscow Oblast
column3: located 34 kilometers (21 mi) east of the Moscow Ring Road on the Klyazma River. Population: 100

column2: the town was later renamed Bogorodsk (lit. [a town] of the Mother of God) by a Catherine the Great's decree in 1781
column3: when it was granted town status. Throughout the 19th century and for a good part of the 20th century
column4: the town was a major textile center
column8: the town  was renamed Noginsk after Bolshevik Viktor Nogin.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Noginsk serves as the administrative center of Noginsky District. As an administrative division
column5: incorporated within Noginsky District as the City of Noginsk. As a municipal division
column6: the City of Noginsk is incorporated within Noginsky Municipal District as Noginsk Urban Settlement.

column1: The city's industrial production is concentrated on ceramics (two major holdings)
column2: food (Biserovo fisheries and a fish factory in Noginsk)
column3: beverage (one of Russia's biggest beverage producers is located near Noginsk)

column2: being the intersection of the Nizhny Novgorod Highway
column4: and the Moscow Minor Ring road.

column1: Rapid transit development plans include possible construction of a direct high-speed railway line connecting Noginsk to the prospective Serp i Molot railway/metro terminal or Shosse Entuziastov metro station. Public transportation system consists of buses and trams. Noginsk's current commuters' travel to and from Moscow on the M7 Moscow-Nizhny-Novgorod Highway. There is also an indirect railway line going through Fryazevo—the line running the first 16 kilometers (9.9 mi) southward
column2: whereas Moscow lies due west of Noginsk. It was built in the late 19th century for the purposes of the textile industry and is still in use.

column1: Vladimir Laptev was the Head of Noginsk until 2005. As of 2014
column2: Vladimir Khvatov serves as the Head of the city.

column1: A guyed mast of a longwave radio broadcasting station is located in Noginsk at 55°50′08″N 38°20′37″E.
the oldest monument to Vladimir Lenin (1924)

column3: a member of the Russian Academy of Sciences

column2: professional football coach and a former player
head of the Russian Orthodox Church
one of the founders of the forensic psychiatry in Russia
